text: North Korea this is what we think North
Korea is like but how does it look and
feel in real life in the next three
minutes I'm going to take you inside the
most isolated country on earth North
Korea and we are getting ready to board
our flight to Pyongyang I had no idea
what was about to happen over the next
three days of my life I was anxious and
nervous we made it I went on a guided
tour around North Korea with Koryo tours
a reputable tour company out of Beijing
before I continue I'd like to disclose
that all tours to North Korea are
heavily organized and pre-planned as to
what we could do eat and see everyone
must stick with their troop at all times
or else they will face severe
consequences also this is not a video
about politics so please make your own
judgments and take everything I say with
a grain of salt I put together a short
video to give you an inside look of
North Korea from my own personal
experiences and I'm not oblivious that
what I saw was a skewed perspective of
the realities that may exist behind
closed doors why did I go to North Korea
other than my journey to visit every
country in the world I've been
fascinated by North Korea since I took a
college class about the DPRK two months
after I graduated college I moved to
South Korea to teach English for 18
months while living in Seoul I
familiarize myself with Korean culture
traditions and I learned how to speak
Korean conversations why are there two
Koreas in the first place on June 25th
1950 the Korean War began when 75,000
soldiers from the north bombarded across
the 38th parallel the boundary between
the Soviet backed communist north and
the pro-western Republic South American
troops soon entered to battle on South
Korea's behalf after three long years in
some five billion casualties later the
Korean War ended and a thick border was
built on the 38th parallel known today
as the Demilitarized Zone the two Koreas
have technically still been at war for
the last 65 years because no peace
treaty has ever been signed on my
three-day tour around North Korea we
stayed in the capital of Pyongyang hey
guys we were here chilling in my hotel
room in Pyongyang it is actually pretty
nice and modern check out this view
outside we covered a lot of ground in
three days and I never once felt unsafe
harassed or in trouble I did feel a
little intimidated by the numerous
military officers and police on every
corner but I knew I'd be fine as long as
I didn't break any rules we walked
through the main squares of Pyongyang
monuments we're at the top of the GJ
tower took the metro ate at restaurants
drank local beer bars sang karaoke
played ping-pong wet boy and went to the
circus I even had the chance to have
conversations in Korean with several
locals which was a special experience
for me
I know what she say one of the
highlights of the trip was running a 10k
in the county we're about to run in the
Pyongyang marriage forget all the people
it started and ended in a giant stadium
filled with 50,000 screaming Koreans it
was an incredible feeling I also enjoyed
taking the underground metro the deepest
public transportation system on earth
and it was bizarre to see thousands of
people on the streets practicing their
celebrations for an upcoming holiday
behind me you can hear all of the
singers and dancers preparing for
communal son's birthday which is in a
few days from what I saw with my own
eyes actually a pretty chill place and
not what I expected to see kids go to
school and make jokes with their friends
adults ride their bikes or take the
metro to work they even have taxis on
the streets it's important to realize
that everyone has hopes and dreams just
like you and me and family time is
important to them they're specifically
talented when it comes to music singing
dancing sports an actor people are
people it's their wedding day we're
taking photos with them that all being
said I did have a strange feeling about
how their society works and how they
portray our country to be for example
there are many tall buildings and wide
streets but limited job opportunities
and hardly anyone has a car many things
felt staged in order to make their
country appear in perfect conditions
very few people in North Korea have
access to the Internet or what's
happening outside of their borders the
information they consume is controlled
by their government which makes me
wonder do the people really know
anything different do they want to leave
North Korea are some people actually
living happy life without us knowing all
my video is saying that my trip to North
Korea was eye-opening and worthwhile to
observe and learn about a hidden culture
I hope that watching my experience
showed you a different side of North
Korea one that you didn't know existed I
left the country with more questions
than I had when I entered as soon as I
got on that plane back to Beijing I
appreciated how lucky I am to have
freedom and the ability to do what I
want say what I want and act I want
please share this video to help me
spread a message of peace positivity and
happiness
